title: 14CO2-based assay for measuring Rubisco activity & activation state
title_html: 14CO2-based assay for measuring Rubisco activity & activation state

authors.name: Cristina Rodrigues Gabriel Sales
authors.affiliation: Lancaster Environment Centre, Lancaster University, Library Avenue, Lancaster, LA1 4YQ, UK

authors.name: Anabela  Silva
authors.affiliation: Biosystems & Integrative Sciences Institute (BioISI), Science Faculty of Lisbon University, Lisbon, 1749-016, Portugal

authors.name: Elizabete Carmo-Silva
authors.affiliation: Lancaster Environment Centre, Lancaster University, Library Avenue, Lancaster, LA1 4YQ, UK

source.description: REAGENTS & SOLUTIONS TO PREPARE BEFOREHAND

Basic extraction buffer (1x)
Bicine-NaOH
MgCl2.6H2O
EDTA
Benzamidine
ε-Aminocaproic acid
  • Dissolve in ultrapure H2O; adjust pH to 8.2 with NaOH; degas the solution bubbling with nitrogen (5 min/100 mL), then add:
  • 2-Mercaptoethanol
  • Adjust for the final volume; it can be dispensed in aliquots (e.g. 50 mL Falcon tubes).
2-Mercaptoethanol

PMSF
Dissolve in ethanol 99%.
Plant protease inhibitor cocktail

Basic assay buffer (2x)
Bicine-NaOH
MgCl2.6H2O
RuBP

source.body: High purity RuBP (≥99%) is required to avoid interference in measurable activity due to the presence of RuBP-analogs that inhibit carboxylation (Kane et al., 1998; Sharwood et al., 2016). It is available commercially or it can be produced enzymatically from AMP-5’ monohydrate and ATP disodium salt (Wong, 1980).

source.description: NaH14CO3 (0.5 Ci/mol)
KOH
Formic acid
Gold Star Quanta scintillation cocktail
SOLUTIONS TO PREPARE JUST BEFORE USE

Complete extraction buffer
1x Basic extraction buffer (from step 1.1)
DTT (from step 1.2)
PMSF (from step 1.3)
Plant protease inhibitor cocktail (from step 1.4)
Prepare the volume considering the number of extractions to be performed throughout the day plus two extras (to have a little excess). Mix all together.

source.body: The volume of extraction buffer will depend on the size of the leaf sample and the protein content, therefore it is species dependent and should be tested beforehand. It is important to ensure that the Rubisco concentration in the assays does not compromise the sensitivity of the assays (e.g. too much would consume all the substrate too quickly).

source.description:
DTT
Dissolve in ultrapure H2O.

Complete assay buffer (volume per vial or reaction)
2x Basic assay buffer (from step 1.5) - final concentration in the solution = 1x
100 mM NaH14CO3 (from step 1.7) - final concentration in the solution = 10 mM
ultrapure H2O
  • Prepare the volume considering that the activities are measured in duplicates (2 technical replicates).
  • If the goal is to assay Rubisco initial and total activities, for each sample extract, it is necessary to have the volume for 4 vials (2 initials + 2 totals).
  • In addition, account for additional volume for at least two more vials for Blanks (background counts, in the asbence of RuBP), plus one extra (to have a little excess).

source.body: Example for 10 extractions: 10x (2xInitial + 2xTotal activity assays) + 2xBlanks + extra = volume for 43 vials.
KH2PO4 can be added in the complete assay buffer for field samples to maximise the measurable Rubisco activity (Carmo-Silva et al., 2017).

source.description:
START
  • Thaw the frozen solutions that will be used in the day.
  • Turn on the heat block and set to the temperature to be used for Rubisco activity measurements.
Turn on the centrifuge and set to
.
Collect samples from
into liquid nitrogen.
Prepare the complete extraction buffer (step 2.1) and the complete assay buffer (step 2.2) and keep it

source.body: The temperature to be used for the Rubisco activity measurement depends on the experiment goals. Typical measurement temperatures are (standard) and , depending on the species. Assays can be performed at a range of temperatures, however special care should be taken at high temperatures (e.g. ), as this can lead to evaporation of the assay mix; rates will be faster, i.e. the assay might become less sensitive; and may cause difficulty in handling hot vials.

source.description: EXTRACTIONS & RUBISCO ASSAYS

Add
    of complete assay buffer (from step 2.2.) to each of the 4 vials.
    Add
    of 30 mM RuBP (from step 1.6) to the 2 vials for initials.

Extraction
  • Add the complete extraction buffer to an ice-cold mortar.
  • Take a sample from the liquid nitrogen container and add to the mortar.
  • Grind the sample thoroughly for
  • to maximum of
  • .
  • Collect the homogenate into an ice-cold 1.5 mL microtube and centrifuge
  • .
  • When centrifugation stops, take the extract supernatant into another ice-cold 1.5 mL microtube.
  • Proceed with the Rubisco assays straight away.
  • Add
  • of sample extract consecutively to each of 4 vials, with 15 s intervals (Total1, Total2, Initial1, Initial2). All additions are completed within 1.5 min of finishing centrifugation.
  • Quench the assays after 30s by adding
  • 10 M formic acid (from step 1.9).
  • A possible time-line for the assays would be:
  • In the interval between quenching initial activities and initiating the reaction for total activities, it is possible to prepare the vials for the next assays (steps 1 and 2 in this table).
  • Repeat for all the extractions of the day.
  • Blanks can be prepared at the start or end of the day, by adding to each vial
  • of complete assay buffer (from step 2.2.) and
  • 10M formic acid (from step 1.9).
  • In addition, it is useful to prepare at least two background checks per experiment by adding to each vial
  • of complete assay buffer (from step 2.2.) ,
  • sample extract, and 3 minutes later
  • 10M formic acid (from step 1.9) to test for background levels of carboxylation due to RuBP that may be present in the leaf extracts. In our hands, this tends to be negligible.
  • Dry all the vials at
  • in the heat block (it takes approximately
  • ).
  • Let vials cool, then add
  • ultrapure H2O to each vial to re-hydrate acid stable compounds. Wait
  • Add
  • of Gold Star Quanta scintillation cocktail (from step 1.10). Close the vials and vortex/mix well.
  • Determine 14C radioactivity using a scintillation counter.

source.body: To prevent Rubisco deactivation (or even denaturation) the extraction should not take more than 1 min and it should be done in a ice-cold mortar, keeping the sample cold at all times. In our hands, with the extraction buffer described (containing protease inhibitors, mercaptoethanol and DTT, which keeps the enzyme reduced) 1 min centrifugation does not impact Rubisco activity. However, this should be tested for each species and extraction buffer used.

The Initial activity assays start with extract addition, while the Total activity assays start with addition of RuBP after 3 min of extract incubation with CO2 and Mg2+ to allow for Rubisco carbamylation.
This protocol can be adapted for measuring Rubisco activity with purified enzyme. In this case, Rubisco is frequently pre-activated and initial activity assays are performed.

We typically do a simple test to verify the total amount of radioactivity present in the complete assay buffer, prepared just before starting the extractions. This serves to verify that the amount of radioactivity in the solution is reliable and comparable accross days of assays. For this,
Add 0.3 M KOH (from step 1.8) plus complete assay buffer (from step 2.2). Add Gold Star Quanta scintillation cocktail (from step 1.10). Close the vial as soon as possible and mix well.

source.description:
Assumptions:
  • NaH14CO3: 0.5 Ci/mol CO2 = 0.5 µCi/µmol CO2
  • 1 µCi = 2220000 disintegration per minute (dpm);
Example:
Blank: 89.03 dpm
Vial 1: 23378.90 dpm
correct vial DPM value by subtracting background counts (Blank):
23378.9 — 89.03=23289.87
dpm
convert dpm to µCi:
23289.87/2220000=0.010491
µCi
convert to CO2 concentration:
0.010491/0.5=0.0210
μmol CO2
Rubisco activity is then converted to the unit of interest by accounting for the reaction time, the volume of sample extract used and the corresponding sample leaf area (µmol CO2 m-2 s-1) or protein content (µmol CO2 min-1 mg-1).
From the Rubisco activity calculations above for initial (Vi) and total activity (Vt), the Rubisco activation state (AS, %) can be calculated:
AS=100×V_i/V_t

description: The Rubisco activity 14CO2-based assay measures the incorporation of 14CO2 into the acid-stable product 3-phosphoglycerate (3-PGA). This protocol is based on Parry et al. (1997).
